awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Transforming Electronic Devices Using Two-dimensional Materials and Ferroelectric Metal Oxides
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract:

Nontechnical description: 
Next generation information technology is driving the quest for energy efficient electronic devices to process unprecedented amounts of data in real time and in an energy- and cost-efficient manner. In this program, the principle investigator (PI) is planning to create and evaluate novel energy efficient electronic devices based on a new hybrid material platform consisting of two-dimensional (2D) materials (mono-/di-chalcogenides and graphene) and ferroelectric metal oxides (doped hafnium and zirconium oxides). The ferroelectric metal oxides provide programmable and non-volatile doping in 2D materials, while the atomically thin bodies in 2D materials enable strong electrostatic control over the channel by the ferroelectric metal oxides. Most previous research on 2D/ferroelectric hybrid materials has focused on traditional perovskite ferroelectric materials. This proposed work will undertake the first systematic study of 2D materials on newly discovered ferroelectric hafnium and zirconium oxides, which have the advantages of excellent scalability, high coercive field, and full compatibility with complementary metal oxide semiconductor (CMOS) technology. The PI's team will investigate the synthesis of this new hybrid material platform and create ultra-low power logic, memory, and analog devices based on these materials. The low power logic and memory devices based on these materials will be essential for mobile devices, medical implantable devices, wearable electronics, and large data centers. Analog classifiers based on these materials will enable high speed and low power signal processing and image recognition systems. 3D integration of these low power 2D ferroelectric devices with high speed silicon circuits will result in next-generation highly parallel and ultra-low power systems to support "Big Data" applications such as the Internet of Things and social media. The PI will integrate research and teaching by creating a new graduate/undergraduate course on 2D materials to train the next generation workforce in nanoelectronics. The PI will establish several outreach activities including a new "Little Einstein" science education program for elementary students to cultivate young minds at an early age to respect and embrace a career in science and technology. The PI will also establish a "Girls Go Tech" program for middle school girls to promote enrollment of female students in science and engineering programs.
Technical description:
The objective of the proposed research is to establish the foundation for a new research direction: nanoelectronics based on 2D/ferroelectric metal oxides hybrid material platform. The PI's team will synthesize and characterize 2D/ferroelectric metal oxide stacks, seeking fundamental understanding of the ferroelectric phase transition in metal oxides with 2D materials as substrate/capping layers. The team will also utilize these materials to create energy efficient logic, memory, and analog devices. Specifically, the team will create and evaluate novel 2D ferroelectric tunneling field effect transistors (2D Fe-TFETs) to serve as ultra-low power logic; will investigate 2D ferroelectric hafnium oxide transistors (2D FHOT) to implement highly energy efficient, scalable, and durable ferroelectric random access memory (FRAM); will create embedded-gate graphene ferroelectric transistors (EGGFTs) to realize highly energy-efficient, extremely compact, and non-volatile analog classifiers. These devices will then be stacked layer-by-layer to realize 3D monolithic integration. This research will elucidate the device physics and evaluate the potential of these devices for future semiconductor technology. The resulting 3D integrated system will provide the hardware foundation for new circuit and architecture designs. This research is potentially transformative as it may unlock new lines of research and development in energy efficient devices, circuits, and architectures with a broad range of emerging applications from wearable electronics and implantable medical devices to data centers.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we demonstrated ferroelectric tunnel junction synapses based on zirconium doped hafnium oxide, which show symmetrical potentiation/depression characteristics, widely tunable conductance and good spike-timing-dependent plasticity. We also demonstrated ferroelectric graphene classifiers, which can calculate the absolute distance between two signals in analog domain and store the reference signal in situ. Furthermore, we studied van der Waals ferroelectrics including indium selenide and copper indium thiophosphate (CIPS). We found that the polarization in indium selenide can be programmed by optical stimuli due to its semiconducting nature, where the photo generated carriers in indium selenide can alter the screening field and lead to polarization reversal. Utilizing these unique properties of indium selenide, we demonstrated a new type of multifunctional device based on 2D heterostructures, which can concurrently serve as a logic gate, photodetector, electronic memory and photonic memory. We systematically investigated the temperature and frequency dependence of the ferroelectric properties of CIPS. We found that there was a large imprint in the CIPS capacitor, which can be attributed to the fixed dipoles induced by defects. Based on the understanding of the ferroelectricity in CIPS, we further investigated the electronic devices based on CIPS heterostructures including CIPS/MoTe2 memory and graphene/ CIPS/graphene multifunctional devices.

Intellectual Merit:

This research will advance the scientific understanding of 2D/ferroelectric hybrid stacks and van der Waals ferroelectrics. This work elucidates the light-polarization interaction in indium selenide, the polarization switching speed and imprint in CIPS, and the impact of capping layer on the remanent polarization in doped hafnium oxide. Furthermore, this research extends the knowledge of novel electronic and photonic devices based on ferroelectric materials, including ferroelectric graphene classifiers, ferroelectric tunneling junctions, multifunctional devices, and ferroelectric memories. The results obtained in this project will help to evaluate the potential of these novel devices for future semiconductor technology.

 

Broader Impacts:

The proposed research will enable a new class of ultra-low power logic, memory, and analog devices for a wide range of emerging applications requiring low cost, high accuracy, and energy efficiency. The novel ferroelectric synapses will have a high potential in both energy-efficient non-volatile memories and artificial neural network applications. The analog classifiers based on graphene ferroelectric transistors will enable high speed and low power signal processing and image recognition systems. Multifunctional devices based on indium selenide will not only increase the packing density of the circuit, but also enable in sensor and in-memory computing architecture, significantly reducing the latency and energy consumption related to the data movement. The integration of the research into education and outreach for K-12 students, new courses for undergraduate/graduate students, and recruiting/retaining women students, will foster students? interest in nanotechnology and broaden students? knowledge base, which will make a long-lasting impact on the education of a world-class and diverse science and technology workforce.
